headline: Grandma Johnson's Scones
description: Using simple ingredients and only 30 minutes, this easy raisin scone recipe is a perfect sweet snack for the whole family.

video.description: See how to make top-rated and time-tested scones.
video.name: Grandma Johnson’s Scones

name: Grandma Johnson's Scones

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, blend the sour cream and baking soda, and set aside.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease a large baking sheet.

In a large bowl, mix the flour, sugar, baking powder, cream of tartar, and salt. Cut in the butter. Stir the sour cream mixture and egg into the flour mixture until just moistened. Mix in the raisins.
Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface, and knead briefly. Roll or pat dough into a 3/4 inch thick round. Cut into 12 wedges, and place them 2 inches apart on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake 12 to 15 minutes in the preheated oven, until golden brown on the bottom.

review.reviewBody: yummy! So good and easy. Followed to a T, except subbed dried blueberries for raisins. Made some triangle, but mostly used a heart shaped cookie cutter. super cute and easy!
My favourite scone recipe! I use dried cranberries and I make mine using a small round cookie cutter and sometimes also sprinkle with cinnamon sugar before baking . These turn out great everytime
Followed the recipe and they taste great. I pasted the sugar and baked at 400. Awesome!
Delicious.....I made them without raisins. The next time I going to added dark chocolate chips.

This has been my base 'go to' recipe for the last 25 years. Everyone loves the resulting scones. One of the base ingredients that I add is white chocolate chips almost every time I've made them. My other favorite additions are diced dried apricots, dried blueberries, raisins, dried cranberries, almost every dried fruit diced.
I love this recipe! When we had our B&B, I'd make it all the time. Seldom put raisins it. Fresh cranberries and orange zest was one of my favorites.

I’ve been making these for years and they are a family favorite. They’re not a traditional hard biscuit-like scone - they’re way better. For best results, use cold butter and chill the cut scones well before baking. My favorite is with semi-sweet chocolate chips mixed in. My daughter likes them with cinnamon chips and cinnamon sprinkled into the dough before baking.

This is a very forgiving scone recipe. I was short 1T-2T of sour cream but decided to go ahead to use up what I had. After trying to get the dough to come together I finally added a couple tablespoons of milk, and voila. I was worried I had overworked the dough, but the scones were beautifully flaky and delicious. I don't think you can go wrong with this recipe. I subbed chocolate chips for the raisins at my sons request and he couldn't stop eating them.
I've made these a dozen times, this recipe is great and I can't help but eat at least a couple while they are fresh! It's nice to find a recipe I don't need to modify!

Another fan of this wonderful recipe. I've frozen it successfully several ways:

Divided the dough in two or three round discs, wrapped and froze. Pull the disc out the night before and thaw in the fridge before baking. 

Cut into wedges, flash froze the dough and placed in zip lock bags in the freezer. 

Baked, iced and frozen them in packages of two scones for any given morning. 

My favorite: Bake the scones, make a powdered sugar glaze, and place each in a zip lock and freeze. So easy to pull them out and let thaw on the counter and then drizzle on the glaze. They still taste fresh! I like to freeze with a glaze pack in bags of six scones and use as quick gifts for friends. 

I find they microwave well from frozen also.

when i made this i did it at 350 degrees for 12 min. it was super soft and almost raw so me and my mom decided to do it at 400 degrees for 14 min. it was perfect except for the fact that i recommend making it with mini chocolate chips if you're using chocolate instead of raisins like me. but it was still super good. i can't put a photo on because it's over 2 MB.
Best recipe ever. Absolutely love these scones!

Thank you so much for sharing your amazing family recipe! My family thoroughly enjoyed them on Father’s Day. My husband likes spices so I lightly added cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves along with a touch of orange extract and raisins. I’ll be sure to use this wonderful recipe in the future for sure! Just perfect! Thanks again.
So good! I put lemon zest and lemon juice in them and glazed before eating with a mix of powdered sugar and lemon zest with some milk- very tasty!! Served with tea

I can't tell you how many times I have made this recipe. Just don't skip steps. I do cut these down because the size recommended is huge. If you enjoy a traditional scone (which is fairly dry), you will Love this recipe too. We like it with dried cranberries or a cran-raisin combo best. Drizzle with a bit of glaze and it is perfect to dunk in my morning coffee.
Delicious! Made these for a teatime.

I halved the recipe and made 16 mini scones. I didn't separate the scones on the pan and they are taking closer to 30 minutes to bake. I froze the butter and grated it, not yet sure if it made any difference.
Love this recipe. I did alter added drued cranberries and orange peel. Turned out yummy

Fabulous! Simple, they were perfect with my first try! My sister shared this recipe with me a few months ago, I had tried several other recipes and never could get one to work. This is now my go to recipe. I have begun experimenting with different fruits and now also using the suggestion to freeze them before baking. So delicious to have fresh scones in just a few minutes. 

One change we both make is to use a 2 1/4 “ round cookie cutter, bake for 17 mins in a gas oven. (Or 2” when a large quantity it desired)

Thank you so much for sharing your family recipe!!! P.S. I so seldom make time to submit a review.
Followed recipe with the exception of fresh blueberries instead of raisins. Turned out great, entire family agreed.

My gentleman friend loves to eat these with his morning coffee but they are delicious no matter what time of day you eat them. In place of raisins, I add chopped dried cranberries or cherries with a splash of vanilla along with almond slivers. You can't go wrong with this recipe.

I have a ton of great scone recipes so I secretly hoped this one didn't match up. But it was delicious. The right mix between moist and crumbly. I made half the batch with chocolate chips for the kids and half with pecans. The pecan batch was just like the expensive scones I'd buy at a coffee shop in NYC.
Not my favorite. Very dry. Didn’t make any changes. Will stick to drop scone
Followed reviewer Lulu Mash's edits
I made this in a whim for my sister-in-law to go with a jar of peach jam I got for her. The scones were yummy! My neice told me her mom hid the majority of them.
First time making scab

Thanks to ‘Rona, I’ve discovered a joy for baking and have made several versions of this and they have all always turned out. I’ve never used raisins (Raisins in cookies are why I have trust issues). Mostly I’ve used chocolate chips, but lately I did dried cranberries and dark chocolate chips, another recipe I did heath toffee bits with mini chocolate chips, and a separate batch with soft caramel bits and mini chocolate chips. I tried frozen blueberries once but had to add a lot of flour to get the dough back to the right consistency. I’ve even been tempted to try it without any mix-ins and coat it in sanding sugar and top with strawberries and whipped cream, but I’m afraid my family and friends are getting tired of me helping add to their quarantine-fifteen.

These turned out great! Not pretty (I wasn’t too careful when I was cutting into pieces. Lol), but very tasty. I made 2 modifications: added 2tsp of pumpkin pie spice to the dry ingredients, then added 1cup of white chocolate chips to the batter instead of raisins. White chocolate pumpkin spice scones! I would totally make these again.
Large delicious scone recipe. They are easy to make and are moist and flavorful. Do not hesitate to try. This many positive reviews can’t be wrong.

I made the magazine version of this recipe. It made 16, not 12. I used Greek yogurt in place of the sour cream as that is what I had on hand. I used dried pear instead of raisins and added 3/4 tsp of cardamom. I think this is a great basic versatile recipe. I will make again for sure. I’m thinking Craisins and orange zest next...

Instead of cream of tartar, I used doubled the amount of lemon juice as a substitute. Replaced the raisins for semi-sweet chocolate chips. Added 1 tsp of vanilla to the beaten egg. Kept the thickness at on inch and baked for the full 15 minutes. Turned out fabulous.

This recipe is amazing and delicious!!! The scones were soft and fluffy and wonderful! I added currants, raisins, and dried orange peel.
I followed a couple of suggestions in the reviews:
1. I beat in a tablespoon of vanilla with the egg before adding it to the flour mixture. 
2. I rolled the dough into 16 balls and slightly flattened them.
They were great, My family isn't a big fan of scones but these were delicious
I don’t get the reviews. These were not like English scones, Slight crunch on the outside, soft yet dense inside, but rather cake-y. Flavor is fine but texture is off in my opinion.
Even people who don't like scones love these!
Absolutely love this recipe! The scones came out so good ! Highly recommend
I love this recipe. You can always make changes to the fruit or whatever you like but this is rock solid.
Love this recipe!
Turned out crumbly but good flavor. Need more practice. Will try again.
These were delicious and very easy to make. Served with homemade strawberry jam!

So many times scones are dry and just....meh. These were heavenly! I'll take a picture the next time we make them. We typically do mini scones....for portion control. It was really hard not to eat them all.

Really good. Trying for Betty’s Fat Rascal on the left side of the pond. Pretty close with orange peel, Small amount of lime peel, 3/4 c whole wheat flour (subbed not extra), and currants instead of raisins. Topped with cherries and almonds. Happy husband, he is from Harrogate and his favorite food in the world is a Betty’s Fat Rascal!
Great recipe!! My family loves these scones. We use chocolate chips instead of raisins. Yum!
These scones are delicious, light and great frozen until ready to make. It's definitely a redo.

I've made this recipe 2 times so far. The first time I used gluten free flour- I ended up adding an additional egg and mik to bind it together. They came out fantastic- not pretty but, DELICIOUS.

The second time I made these, I followed the recipe to the letter. Served with mock devonshire cream and homemade persimmon jam. They were equally DELICIOUS. Took them to work, and they were devoured within minutes.
Delicious scones!! My mother in law makes them all the time and I’m about to make them for my second!
nice
Raves for these scones from the family and friends I allowed to taste! I have to make again as I only got one scone! Easy and wonderful recipe.

A wonderfully moist scone! With No sour cream in my refrigerator, I had to substitute with plain yogurt. Besides decreasing a few calories, the yogurt worked out quite well. Also, I did use Golden Raisins—these are more moist which I personally prefer over the darker varieties. My family & friends loved the finished product!

I followed the directions in the FEB/MAR 2020 edition of the printed magazine - 400 degrees, and I used dried blueberries. I brushed them with cream and sprinkled with raw cane turbinado sugar. My wife commented that they were much better than the ones I usually make - I agree. Best scones I've ever had.

The scones just came out of the oven...this recipe is a true keeper...I’ve been in search of this and found it in the Allrecipes magazine (Feb/Mar 2020
issue)...thanks!
Shirley
I don’t usually like scones but these were bomb!
Yup...great scones! And, I love being able to add anything to the recipe...in my case I added milk chocolate chips and dried orange cranberries. I found this recipe to be very easy!

Mmmm...I love this recipe so much that I made them for Christmas morning! I've made them 10 - 12 times over the Holidays. Everybody loves them!! Most of the time I made half batches so I made them more often. I always use frozen butter and cut it into the flower mixture. Sometimes, I split the half batch again and put raisins in half and cranberry relish in the other. The cranberry relish ones are a bit more moist dough, but cook up the same. Thank You for sharing Grandma Johnson's Scones recipe!
Recipe was simple and easy dough gets super thick I recommend using a mixer if possible. I substituted raisins for cranberries and added a light glazed drizzle. They were delicious.
These are the most delicious scones I ever made... Me and my family just love these.... Plus the recipe is so simple to follow
Excellent. Just the right balance of taste and texture. Was a hit at home.
Very easy and consistent. I made 3 batches that were gone by the time they hit the buffet

Best scone ever!

I made mine with cranberries and they were the perfect sweetness and they were more biscuit than cookie. Will definitely make again!
I shaped this into 2 circles and cut each into even wedges and will freeze one before baking. Hope that works. The one I baked came out great.
Instead of the raisins, we added a little over 1 cup of fresh blueberries. YUM!!
I tried a few recipes for scones but this is the best. My family loves it when I make these scones!
Love it! Have used different add ins, think my fav is chopped dried cherries. My son's fav is orange zest with dried cranberries.
Excellent! I would make it again but pat into 2 smaller circles instead of 1 large one. Would also be good with craisins or blueberries
Yummy - made w chocolate chips and sprinkled cinnamon sugar on top
First time to make scones. Followed recipe exactly, and they turned out perfectly delicious. Thank you for this recipe. Lemon curd is the ideal complement.
The scones itself were alright, but the raisins threw it off. It needed more sugar, and also chocolate chips would have been good.

Followed what another reviewer recommended and added the egg to the sour cream mixture along with 1 teaspoon of vanilla. At the end, added orange zest from 2 oranges and 1 cup of dried cranberries (omitted the raisins). Once the scones were cooled drizzled an orange glaze made of 1/2 cup icing sugar, 1 tbsp orange juice, and 1/2 tsp orange zest over the scones. Next time if using a glaze on the scones would reduce the sugar in the scone recipe to 3/4 cup so that they don't get too sweet with a glaze added to them.

An absolutely delicious recipe! Really easy to follow instructions and loved by the whole family! Definitely plan on making these again! I did although follow the recipe by LULU MASH to make it moist! Turned out fantastic!

These are great but VERY buttery. Next time I will definitely use less butter. The only thing I had trouble with in making the scones was incorporating the sour cream and egg. I used a plastic spatula but eventually had to switch to a wooden spoon because it wasn't mixing enough. I thought I had put in too much flour at first, but it ended up looking like the video once I switched. I strongly recommend using a wooden spoon at the sour cream and egg step, but other than that they were great!
Excellent! Tender and sweet. No raisins for me tho. I zested a lemon and added a squeeze of juice. Second time i also added a cup of fresh blueberries. Very versatile. Thanks!!!
It very good

I followed the directions step by step and thought it was too dry at the kneading stage. Tried to clump it together on a tray. Added some milk wash and sugar to one tray in the hopes of saving them. Turns out, they were delicious. Next time, I'll be more careful mixing the dry and the wet ingredients to better incorporate all of it. The flavors were spot on. This is a keeper.

I have been using this recipe for years and love it. While I am known for adjusting recipes I found no need to change this one. These are moist and quite tasty. Try your own stir in ideas as this is a great base recipe for various flavored scones.

These were so good! I did what some of the others recommended. Reduced the sugar a bit. Divided the dough and did one with chocolate chips, the other with cranberry, orange zest and cinnamon. Extras to put in the freezer.

This is basically foolproof if you measure the ingredients carefully. I made them with orange zest and thawed, chopped cranberries. My baking time was 22 minutes, so I concur with several other reviews. I found it was important to make sure the scones were uniformly sliced and of the same thickness to bake evenly. I cut them smaller, so it yielded 24 scones, and they’re plenty big. I can’t wait to try these with additional flavors.
The best scones ever. My kids beg me to make these (I add cinnamon chips). Not as dense or dry as most scones. It’s my go-to recipe!!
ive made these scones several times and they are a big hit every single time. i do variations as well with different flavors but always the same base, followed to the T.

This is definitely my “go to” scone recipe! Our family loves them! I’ve done 2 variations 1-fresh blueberries and topped the scones with a drizzle of lemon flavored icing and 2- dried cranberries with a drizzle of orange flavored icing.

These scones really. are the best. I’ve been making them for over 15 years. I use craisins that I chop up & soak in orange juice for an hour or so. I divide the dough in half & make 2 rounds. I cut each round into 8 wedges. I brush with egg wash & lightly sprinkle with sugar before baking. **NOTE: do NOT over bake or they’ll dry out, cook just until edges are slightly golden.

These are amazing! I've made blueberry lemon, almond raisin, and cranberry orange. I've made the recipe to make 12-14 large scones and 24-30 small ones. The only thing I noticed is that they need a little more baking time than recommended. 

A tip...mix in the wet ingredients and then let it sit for five minutes before rolling out. Much easier to work with.
I didn't make any changes. However it tastes more like cake rather than scones. It was crunchy outside and soft inside. My daughter likes them anyway. A bit sweet as well with flaky crust. Thanks

Delicious!!!!
Used mini chocolate chips instead of raisins.
They were huge and so good.
Very tasty, I cut the sugar down to 1/3 cup and added 1/4 cup semi sweet chocolate chips.
This is a sweet scone. Followed recipe as is. Used dried sour cherries and added cinnamon in one half of the batch and made the other half plain.
Best scones and easy to make. I put huckleberries in my scones and they turned out sooooo yummy!

These scones are amazing. Some tips - the butter needs to be COLD. I use a food processor to cut mine into the flour (put about half the flour/sugar mix into the processor, slice up all the butter into 1tbsp chunks and add them to the flour, then pulse until butter is cut in to desired size). Also, once you add the sour cream and egg, if the mixture seems TOO dry or crumbly, press it into a big mound in the bowl and let it rest for 3-4 minutes. I generally add toffee or cinnamon chips at this stage, then knead dough to incorporate the chips, then roll out.
This is a great recipe,!
These never make it past a couple days in our house. Anyone and everyone that tried these rave about them so this is for sure my gosh to recipe for scones forever more !
Awesome!!! It worked really well, one thing, don't overmix it! If you do, they won't be as light or flakey as a traditional scone, but they will still taste really good.
This recipe came out amazing I followed it word for word and they came out beautifully, the family definitely wants me to make them again
The recipe is VERY DRY! I had to put the whole mess back in the bowl and sprinkle some water just to get it to stick together. By then, it was overworked. I think I will just go to Panera next time.

This is my first time making this recipe. It is the best I’ve ever made. Light and fluffy and flavor is awesome. I accidentally used two eggs instead of one and it still turned out awesome. The texture is amazing. I also used the tin foil on the pan. Easy clean up. Awesome. Will make again.
Turned out great!
Made these as part of a large breakfast (3) to feed 750 people approx.....always good!

Great versatile recipe. I use it to make cinnamon chip scones. Everybody that knows me wants these. Tip. ALWAYS USE COLD BUTTER!! Do not substitute the butter for anything else. Trust me. You want to follow the basic recipe. You won't be sorry. 
PS... USE ONLY REAL, COLD BUTTER.

They did surprise even me: I love scones but I am usually defending them against detractors who are perpetually saying that scones are not really cakes, not really bread, not really worth the effort, not really satysfying enough and so on and so on. So yes, I am a regular scones champion, but this recipe brought them over the top. I just wanted to make this batch as plain as possible, I was in a hurry, I checked the pantry and no raisins, my husband was putting pressure as we were to go out... a culinary disaster in the making! but oh my, these were no fuss and sooo gooood!!! instead of raisins I only had a mix of dried cranberries and raspberries, and didn't remember to add them till the dough was ready and packed. Maybe all this heartburn was the reason of the success of this recipe: minimum handling and baking. They were perfect, everyone was marveling on the light texture and the wonderful flakiness. Can't wait to try not all the fancy different combinations (lemon orange, white choc, and cinnamon, apples, and so on) only but strawberry jam and cream even.
I've never made scones but these turned out delicious. I did follow Lulu Mash's instructions from her review. I brought them to a tea and the recipe was requested. I will make these again.

I made these today and they turned out great!! My husband and I both agreed they were the best I've ever made! To clarify with some other reviewers, the butter definitely must be cold and not room temperature (cold butter is standard for all scones). I'm on vacation and didn't have cream of tartar and they still turned out great. I will make these again when I get home to see if they turn out much different with cream of tartar. I divided the dough in half, made orange/craisin and chocolate/walnut, both were delicious!
